div.p: Which Student Behaviours Require a Response?
The Ministry now requires employees of a board who work directly with children and who observe
a student behaving in a way that is likely to have a negative impact on school climate
to respond to the behaviour. These behaviours include racist, sexual, sexist,
or homophobic comments, slurs, and jokes or graffiti, as well as activities for which
suspension and expulsion must be considered.
Who Must Respond?
This requirement applies to all board employees who work directly with students.
This includes, but is not limited to, teachers, support staff in social work, child and youth
work, psychology, and related areas, as well as educational assistants.
What Does Responding Look Like?
Responding may include asking a student to stop the inappropriate behaviour, naming the
type of behaviour and explaining why it is inappropriate and/or disrespectful, and asking
the student for a change in future behaviour. For an example of an effective board practice, see
How to Handle Harassment in the Hallways in Three Minutes (from the Toronto District School
Board) in the Resources section.
Let's look at an example of responding.
BALLER #2: Woah! Nice shot! Let's go.
BALLER #1: Ew! What was that? Seriously! What was that? You shoot like a retard!
BALLER #2: You're the retard!
BALLER #1: You know you're the retard. Well you are a retard.
BALLER #2: You talk like a retard. BALLER #1: Well, you're the retard.
BALLER #2: You look like a retard. BALLER #1: You're the retard.
BALLER #2: You walk like a retard. BALLER #1: Retard.
BALLER #2: You play like a retard. BALLER #1: Retard.
BALLER #2: Your face is a retard.
BALLER #1: You're a retard. Period. You are the retard.
BALLER #2: You look like a retard. BALLER #1: Well you are a retard.
BALLER #2: You talk like a retard. BALLER #1: Well you're the retard.
BALLER #2: You walk like a retard. TEACHER: Hey boys, boys, can you stop the
name-calling? Last time I checked, that was never a nice thing to say to anyone. It certainly
doesn't fit with our school's Code of Conduct. Imagine how you would feel if you or someone
close to you was developmentally delayed and you heard that kind of talk.
BALLER #1: We're just joking around, we don't really mean it.
TEACHER: We don't joke around like that at this school. Next time, try to think a bit more before
you say something that can hurt people. See you tomorrow boys.
And Aaron, remember, it's all in the wrist.
BALLER #2: Thank you. BALLER #1: Yeah.
What Are the Exceptions?
Board employees are not required to respond if responding would, in the employee's opinion,
cause immediate physical harm to himself or herself or to that of a student or another person.
For example, a staff member working with a special needs student, may not respond if doing
so would mean leaving the student unattended, potentially placing them in
immediate physical danger.
However, board employees are expected to verbally inform the principal as soon as
possible if they do not immediately respond.
There are many new things to consider and discuss. We'll look at what the new legislation
has to say about supporting students, then move on to some more live scenarios to
illustrate and help us understand these new requirements.
